The hydrodynamic version of the Schrödinger equation or the Klein-Gordon equation describes the evolution of a quantum system in terms of its fluid-like behavior. It is based on the idea that the wave function can be interpreted as a probability density and the current density associated with it can be interpreted as a fluid velocity.

In the hydrodynamic formulation of the Schrödinger equation, the wave function is expressed as a product of a complex amplitude and a phase, and the amplitude is interpreted as a density function of the fluid. The Schrödinger equation is then reformulated as a set of equations that describe the conservation of mass and momentum for the fluid.

Similarly, in the hydrodynamic formulation of the Klein-Gordon equation, the wave function is also expressed as a product of an amplitude and a phase, and the amplitude is interpreted as a charge density. The Klein-Gordon equation is then reformulated as a set of equations that describe the conservation of charge and momentum for the fluid.

The hydrodynamic formulation of the Schrödinger or Klein-Gordon equations has several advantages over the traditional formulations. It provides a more intuitive understanding of the behavior of quantum systems, particularly in terms of fluid dynamics. It also allows for the application of well-established techniques from classical fluid mechanics, such as shock wave analysis and turbulence theory, to quantum systems.

However, the hydrodynamic formulation has some limitations, particularly in cases where the wave function is highly non-local or non-separable. In such cases, the hydrodynamic equations may not accurately capture the behavior of the quantum system.

Overall, the hydrodynamic formulation of the Schrödinger or Klein-Gordon equations provides a useful tool for studying the fluid-like behavior of quantum systems, particularly in cases where the traditional formulations are not applicable.
